This cession of the towns to their enemies the Portugueze, they thought must have been imposed on them by way of punishment; ⁷ though they were at a loss to imagine what crime they could have committed deserving such punishment, unless to have served God and the King were accounted such.

This universal doubt impressed on the minds of the Indians, respecting the royal order for their removal, was confirmed by a most im- pudent lie, invented by certain wicked knaves amongst the lower order of Spaniards3 who assured the Indians that the removal enjoined in the King’s name was a sabrication of the J esuitS, they having themselves sold those towns to the Portugueze, out of a thirst for gold. The Guaranies, possessed with this abominable sus- picion, grew more and more deas to the admo- nitions of the J esuits‚ who, through respect to the King, were constantly urging their depar- ture. The filial affection which they had always borne to the Fathers being destroyed, they began openly to reject the authority of others, and to manage every thing according to their own pleasure.
